title: Pakistan was never technical ally of US: White House's John Kirby - Geo News
summary:
Pakistan Was Never a Technical Ally of the US, Says John Kirby

Publication Date: December 7, 2023 | Source: Geo TV

White House official John Kirby clarified that Pakistan has never been a tactical ally of the United States during a press briefing. Despite this clarification, Kirby acknowledged the collaborative efforts between the US and Pakistan in counter-terrorism.

  • There was no treaty of alliance with Pakistan, says Kirby.
  • Acknowledges Pakistan and the US joined hands against terrorism.
  • The administration remains committed to working with Pakistan.
“Pakistan was never a technical ally of the United States. I mean, there was no treaty of alliance with Pakistan,” - John Kirby

Kirby emphasized ongoing US commitment to working with Pakistan to address mutual threats and challenges, which include terrorism stemming from the Afghanistan-Pakistan border.
newTitle: Pakistan Was Never a Technical Ally of the US, Says John Kirby

title: Biden bids farewell from Oval Office as Trump looms over his legacy - Reuters
Impeached President Yoon arrested in second attempt: What is behind the action-packed month in South Korea - The Indian Express
summary:
Impeached President Yoon arrested in second attempt: What is behind the action-packed month in South Korea

Date: January 15, 2025   Source: Indian Express

South Korea's impeached President Yoon Suk-yeol was arrested amid escalating political drama, following weeks of protests and two failed impeachment attempts.

  • Yoon Suk-yeol's presidency has been marked by controversies, including his attempt to impose martial law in December 2024.
  • In response to public outrage and parliamentary action, he was impeached and later arrested on charges of insurrection.
  • The political crisis intensified with the impeachment of Prime Minister Han Duck-soo and investigations into alleged treason related to North Korea.
  • Yoon's arrest followed a failed attempt to resist authorities, leading to clashes with supporters and law enforcement.
Yoon stated he agreed to cooperate with the “illegal investigation” to “prevent unsavoury bloodshed”.

This incident marks a significant moment in South Korea's political landscape, raising questions about the future of governance and stability in the region.
newTitle: Impeached President Yoon Arrested: Unpacking South Korea's Political Turmoil

title: How latest US sanctions on Russia’s oil trade might affect India’s crude imports - The Indian Express
summary:
US Sanctions on Russia's Oil Trade Could Impact India's Crude Imports

Publication Date: January 10, 2024 | Source: Indian Express

The recent sanctions by the United States targeting Russia's oil trade may significantly affect India's crude oil imports, as Russia has become India's main supplier since the war in Ukraine.

  • The US imposed sanctions on 183 tankers crucial for transporting Russian oil, impacting major consumers like India and China.
  • This sanctions package is the largest since Russia's invasion of Ukraine and aims to reduce Moscow's oil revenue.
  • India has relied heavily on Russian oil, with 38% of its total imports stemming from Russia in 2024.
  • Indian refiners plan to refuse oil from sanctioned vessels after March 12, with an expectation of increased imports from West Asia.
  • The sanctions have prompted Russia to seek ways to navigate the impact on its oil exports.
“The swift sanctions aim to disrupt Russian oil exports, forcing sellers to seek alternative vessels to address the shipping shortfall—a challenge that will take time to resolve.” - Matt Wright, Kpler’s lead freight analyst.

In conclusion, while immediate impacts may be mitigated, the long-term landscape for India's crude oil imports may shift significantly towards West Asian suppliers.
newTitle: US Sanctions on Russia's Oil Trade Could Impact India's Crude Imports

title: China Removes “Geo-Fencing” From DJI Drones In The US; Chinese UAVs Can Now “Fly” Over White House - EurAsian Times
summary:
China Removes 'Geo-Fencing' From DJI Drones In The US; Chinese UAVs Can Now 'Fly' Over White House

Date: January 3, 2025 | Source: Eurasian Times

The Chinese drone manufacturer DJI has announced the removal of geo-fencing from its drones in the US, allowing them greater freedom of operation. The update, effective from January 2025, aligns DJI's regulations with the FAA's newly proposed drone rules.

  • The geo-fencing removal means DJI drones can now fly over restricted areas, including the White House and military bases.
  • This update has raised concerns following a recent incident where a DJI drone collided with a firefighting aircraft in Los Angeles.
  • DJI argues that drone regulations have evolved significantly, making previous restrictions unnecessary.
  • Operators are now responsible for navigating controlled airspace with the help of an updated software system that provides alerts instead of locking out flights entirely.
  • The DJI Mavic 3 Thermal Enterprise is priced significantly lower than its US competitors, which may lead to wider market implications.
“DJI aims to put control back in the hands of drone operators, ensuring compliance with FAA regulations.”

This change has sparked debates about airspace safety and regulatory oversight as drone usage increases, particularly in sensitive areas.
newTitle: China Removes 'Geo-Fencing' From DJI Drones In The US; Chinese UAVs Can Now 'Fly' Over White House

TikTok prepares for shutdown in US this Sunday. What does it mean? - Hindustan Times
summary:
TikTok prepares for shutdown in US this Sunday. What does it mean?

Date: Jan 15, 2025 Source: Hindustan Times

TikTok is set to shut down for US users due to a federal ban take effect. A new law requires TikTok to be sold off from its parent company ByteDance or face a ban.

  • TikTok plans to shut down the app for US users starting this Sunday.
  • The shutdown follows a new law signed by President Biden in April 2024.
  • If the ban is enacted, users may not be able to download the app, though current users can still use it temporarily.
  • TikTok will provide users with a pop-up message directing them to details about the ban.
  • The company is aiming to allow users to download their personal data before shutting down.
  • TikTok claims that one-third of 170 million American users would stop using the app if the ban lasts over a month.
"One-third of the 170 million Americans who use the app would stop doing so if the ban lasts over a month."

This shutdown marks a significant development regarding the regulation of social media platforms in the US, with implications for users and the broader social media landscape.
newTitle: TikTok Prepares for Shutdown in the US this Sunday: Implications and Details

summary:
All about androgynosexuality and why it is gaining popularity among Gen Z

Date: January 15, 2025 / Source: Moneycontrol

As society’s understanding of sexuality evolves, new terms are emerging to reflect diverse attractions and identities. Among these, “androgynosexuality” is witnessing a remarkable surge in popularity.

  • The term has seen a 250% increase in 2024, according to dating app Feeld.
  • The hashtag #androgynosexuality has millions of views on TikTok, with many explanatory videos.
  • It combines traits of attraction to both masculine and feminine traits, appealing to bigender, gender-neutral, or non-binary individuals.
  • One TikTok video explaining the term has garnered over three million views.

The emergence of androgynosexuality marks a notable shift in the discourse around gender and attraction in modern society.

title: Hamas Accepts Gaza Ceasefire Draft Agreement, Hostage Release Plan: Report - NDTV
summary:

Publication Date: November 2023, Source: Associated Press

Palestine-based Hamas has accepted a ceasefire and hostage release draft agreement amid the ongoing conflict with Israel. Negotiations in Qatar have brought both sides closest to concluding the deal.

  • Marathon talks in Qatar have brought progress towards a ceasefire.
  • The U.S., Egypt, and Qatar are involved in finalizing the agreement.
  • Hamas is expected to release 33 Israeli hostages.
  • Israeli forces' withdrawal will be phased but maintain border defense.
  • Increased humanitarian aid is planned for Gaza amidst a severe crisis.
“It’s closer than it’s ever been before,” - US Secretary of State Antony Blinken

The outcome of these negotiations holds significant implications for the future governance of Gaza and the humanitarian situation in the region.

title: New Canada Open Work Permit Eligibility Effective January 21 - INC – Immigration News Canada
summary:
New Canada Open Work Permit Eligibility Effective January 21

Date: Last Updated On 14 January 2025

Source: Immigration News Canada

The Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) has announced changes to eligibility criteria for Open Work Permits for family members of international students and foreign workers, effective January 21, 2025. These changes aim to align temporary resident programs with Canadian economic objectives.

Key Points

  • Spouses of International Students: Eligibility is based on the student's program length and type.
  • Spouses of Foreign Workers: Only eligible if the foreign worker has a permit for high-skill jobs or in sectors facing labor shortages.
  • Dependent children will no longer be eligible for family OWPs.
  • Current holders of family OWPs will remain valid until expiry but must meet new criteria for renewals.
  • Exceptions include free-trade agreements and pathways to permanent residency.
  • Alternative options for those no longer eligible are available under broader immigration permits.

Notable Quotes

“The changes to the Open Work Permit eligibility for family members of international students and foreign workers in Canada are poised to redefine who can call Canada home, at least temporarily.”

Conclusion

As these new policies roll out, their effects on Canada’s immigration landscape and economy will be closely monitored, raising questions about the balance between skilled workforce objectives and family unity.
newTitle: New Canada Open Work Permit Eligibility Effective January 21

South Korea’s impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol was arrested, marking the first time a sitting president has been detained. Yoon faces charges of insurrection over his imposition of martial law.

  • More than 1,000 police officers made a careful attempt to detain Yoon amid barriers and blockades.
“Today, when I saw them invading the security perimeter with fire equipment, I decided to appear before the CIO, even though it is an illegal investigation.” — Yoon Suk Yeol

The arrest symbolizes significant political turmoil in South Korea, as the Constitutional Court deliberates Yoon's potential reinstatement amidst charges against him. The situation has drawn widespread attention both nationally and internationally.
